title: Ken Sio
text:
Ken Sio (born 29 October 1990) is an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays on the for the <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford Red Devils</a> in the <a href="Betfred%20Super%20League">Betfred Super League</a>. 
He has previously played for the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> and the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> and <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> in the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a>.
Background.
Sio was born in <a href="Blacktown">Blacktown, New South Wales</a>, Australia.
Playing career.
Having played his junior football for the <a href="Wentworthville%20Magpies">Wentworthville Magpies</a>, Sio went on and played in the <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">Under 20s Toyota Cup</a> in the 2009 and 2010 seasons for the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a>.
Going on to train with the first-grade side before breaking his leg in a trial game in 2011, Sio returned halfway through the season for the <a href="Cabramatta%20Two%20Blues">Cabramatta Two Blues</a> in the <a href="Bundaberg%20Red%20Cup">Bundaberg Red Cup</a>.
Parramatta Eels (2011–14).
Sio made his <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a> début in round 26 of the 2011 season, he played on the against the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a>, also scoring his début try in the same match.
In June 2011, he re-signed with the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> until 2014, along with teammates <a href="Matt%20Ryan%20%28rugby%20league%29">Matt Ryan</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Paulo">Joseph Paulo</a> respectively.
Sio was seen as the shining light in 2012, which was a terrible season for the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> as they finished last on the table for the first time since 1972, he scored 13 tries and subsequently came 6th in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>'s top try scorers table for the season.
He was injured in round 1 of the <a href="2013%20NRL%20season">2013</a> season against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">Warriors</a>, in which he was replaced by debutant, <a href="Vai%20Toutai">Vai Toutai</a>. Sio returned from injury to play 20 games for Parramatta in 2013 and scored 10 tries but it was not enough to save Parramatta from a second consecutive wooden spoon.
In the <a href="2014%20NRL%20season">2014 NRL season</a>, Sio scored 13 tries in 12 games as Parramatta narrowly missed the finals.
Hull Kingston Rovers (2015-16).
On 31 July 2014, Sio signed a contract to play for <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> club <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> from 2015.
On 8 February 2015, he made his début for <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> in round 1 of the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> season against the <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds Rhinos</a>. He then scored his first-ever <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> try against the <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity Wildcats</a> in round 2.
He represented the club in the <a href="2015%20Challenge%20Cup">2015 Challenge Cup</a> Final.
Sio suffered relegation from the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> with <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> in the 2016 season, due to losing the <a href="Million%20Pound%20Game">Million Pound Game</a> by the <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford Red Devils</a>.
That same game proved to be Sio's last appearance for <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>, as he went onto join the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a> ahead of the <a href="2017%20NRL%20season">2017 NRL season</a>.
Newcastle Knights (2017-18).
On 31 October 2016, Sio signed a 2-year contract to return to the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a> with the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a>.
In the <a href="2017%20NRL%20season">2017 NRL season</a>, Sio played 21 games and scored 5 tries as Newcastle finished last on the table for a third straight season.
On 21 April 2018, in round 7 of the <a href="2018%20NRL%20season">2018 season</a>, Sio scored his first <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> of tries for <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle</a> in their 22-20 win over the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a> at <a href="Tamworth%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Tamworth</a>.
Sio failed to come to terms with the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a> over a new deal to remain at the club, after a well documented dispute over a contract that they had offered him previously, Sio then subsequently took the decision to make his return to the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a>.
Salford Red Devils (2019 - present).
It was revealed on 18 October 2018, that Sio had signed a three-year contract to play for the <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford Red Devils</a> in the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> ahead of the 2019 season.
Sio made his début for the <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford Red Devils</a> on 1 February 2019, in a 14-34 victory over the <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield Giants</a> at the <a href="John%20Smiths%20Stadium">John Smiths Stadium</a>.
He played in the <a href="2019%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">2019 Super League Grand Final</a> defeat by <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a>.
In round 22 of the <a href="2021%20Super%20League%20season">2021 Super League season</a>, Sio scored four tries for Salford in a 42-14 victory over <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a>.
Representative.
On <a href="International%20rugby%20league%20in%202021%23June">25 June 2021</a> he played for the <a href="Combined%20Nationalities%20rugby%20league%20team">Combined Nations All Stars</a>, and scored two tries, in their 26-24 victory over <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a>, staged at the <a href="Halliwell%20Jones%20Stadium">Halliwell Jones Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a>, as part of England’s <a href="2021%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2021 Rugby League World Cup</a> preparation.
